newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Sydney air traffic growth boosts new airport plan.
newsitem.headline: Sydney air traffic growth boosts new airport plan.

text.p: Sydney's air traffic growth is far exceeding expectations, reinforcing the new Australian government's plans for a second major airport for the city, a report issued on Wednesday showed.

By the end of the next decade, about 40 million passengers a year would use the airport, compared with the current 20 million a year and the previous forecast of 18 million for 2010 by 1985 estimates, the Transport Department reported.
Booming tourism and industry deregulation, which has driven down airfares, had pushed traffic growth above earlier expectations, Transport Minister John Sharp said in a statement.
"The projected substantial high growth rates in aviation activity in the Sydney basin highlight the need for a second major airport," he said.
Australian international traffic would grow at between seven and nine percent between now and 2010, compared with the worldwide industry's five percent, the minister said.
Sydney's air traffic, essential to business travel and the tourism industry, is a national political problem.

The current airport, in the suburb of Mascot, is just a 20 minute taxi ride from the city centre, which makes it as convenient for travellers as it is unpopular with residents living under the flightpaths.

Sydneysiders have long demanded the airport be replaced, but the former Labor government approved its expansion in the 1980s while developing a distant plan for a new airport in the city's far west, about an hour's drive away from its centre.

Little progress has since been made on the new airport, which in any case would only have taken a small part of the traffic, mainly smaller aircraft and freight, while the main operations stayed at Mascot.
The current Liberal-National government is looking at a closer site for a new airport and insists it should be a full-scale installation, taking much of the load off Mascot.
However, even Sharp does not expect the new airport to replace Mascot.

"For historic and economic reasons, Mascot will still be the major airport, simply because that's where the two major airlines have got their facilities," he said, referring to Qantas Airways Ltd and Ansett Airlines Ltd.
"But the importance and significance of the second airport will grow as the amount of traffic grows and the increase in traffic is steered towards the second airport."
The new airport would be able to handle 360,000 take-offs and landings a year, compared with Sydney's current 270,000 and the 426,000 projected for the end of the next decade, he said.
The new government came to office last year promising to spread out the air traffic over Sydney, sharing out the noise that Labor had concentrated over a few suburbs.
Flight paths were changed last year but on Wednesday Sharp issued another plan for Sydney airport that would shift more aircraft away from residential areas.
